DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold UP
DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed against most major foreign currencies in quiet European trading late this morning. Gold prices also rose. Traders said movements were exaggerated in the thin pre-Christmas market. ``In this market, small amounts are enough to move the dollar,'' said one trader in Milan, Italy. ``It's really Christmas that's fixing the market,'' said another. ``Most people are staying out just to look.'' Dealers in Frankfurt said the dollar staged a small technical recovery overnight on rumors of imminent changes in key Japanese interest rates. The rumors resulted in the selling of marks and buying of yen, which firmed the dollar-mark rate, they said. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.42 yen to a closing 143.80 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 143.90 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.7318 West German marks, up from 1.7245 _1.5546 Swiss francs, up from 1.5480 _5.9185 French francs, up from 5.8890 _1.9533 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9455 _1,292.00 Italian lire, up from 1,289.25 _1.1610 Canadian dollars, unchanged In London, the dollar fell slightly against the British pound. It cost $1.6038 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6020 late Monday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $413.90 a troy ounce, up from $409.25 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's five major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $411.30. In Zurich, the bid price was $411.25, up from $408.50 bid late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $1.83 to close at a bid $412.80. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.57 a troy ounce from Monday's $5.55.
